facts.text: This is a Civil Appeal No.1850 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION- Civil Appeal No.1850 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 30,

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 30, 1966 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 102 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 30, 1966 of the Calcutta High Court in. Income-tax Reference No. 102 of 1962. N. Banerjee and P. K. Mukherjee, for the appellants.

facts.text: The assessee was assessed in the status of an individual.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was assessed in the status of an individual. He derived income from house properties and from the business of a registered partnership firm H. Ganguly Co. He had six houses one of which was 24, Mohanlal Street, Calcutta and the other at Janganbari in the city of Banaras.

facts.text: Assessee derived income from house properties and from the business of a registered partnership firm H. Ganguly Co.

anchor.surface_text: He derived income from house properties and from the business of a registered partnership firm H. Ganguly Co. He had six houses one of which was 24, Mohanlal Street, Calcutta and the other at Janganbari in the city of Banaras. On March 19, 1953 the see, created a trust in respect of these two houses.

facts.text: Assessee had six houses.

anchor.surface_text: He had six houses one of which was 24, Mohanlal Street, Calcutta and the other at Janganbari in the city of Banaras. On March 19, 1953 the see, created a trust in respect of these two houses. It was provided in the trust deed that the trustees shall pay a sum of Rs. 200/- per month to the settlor for life for his own absolute use and benefit out of the income of the trust estate remaining after payment of taxes, rents etc.

It was provided in the trust deed that the trustees shall pay a sum of Rs. 200/- per month to the settlor for life for his own absolute use and benefit out of the income of the trust estate remaining after payment of taxes, rents etc.

facts.text: On March 19, 1953 the assessee created a trust in respect of these two houses.

anchor.surface_text: On March 19, 1953 the see, created a trust in respect of these two houses. It was provided in the trust deed that the trustees shall pay a sum of Rs. 200/- per month to the settlor for life for his own absolute use and benefit out of the income of the trust estate remaining after payment of taxes, rents etc. In other words he himself was one of the beneficiaries.

facts.text: Trust deed provided that trustees shall pay Rs. 200/- per month to the settlor for life for his own absolute use and benefit out of the income of the trust estate after payment of taxes, rents etc.

anchor.surface_text: It was provided in the trust deed that the trustees shall pay a sum of Rs. 200/- per month to the settlor for life for his own absolute use and benefit out of the income of the trust estate remaining after payment of taxes, rents etc. In other words he himself was one of the beneficiaries. The Income tax Officer held that the income from the afore- said two properties was assessable in the hands Of the assessee inasmuch as he had retained a portion of the income from the trust properties for himself.

facts.text: Assessee was one of the beneficiaries of the trust.

anchor.surface_text: In other words he himself was one of the beneficiaries. The Income tax Officer held that the income from the afore- said two properties was assessable in the hands Of the assessee inasmuch as he had retained a portion of the income from the trust properties for himself. The trust had, therefore, become revocable under the provisions of s. 16  1    c  of the income tax Act 1922, hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: Income tax Officer held that the income from the two properties was assessable in the hands of the assessee as he retained a portion of the income, making trust revocable u/s 16(1)(c) of 1922 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Income tax Officer held that the income from the afore- said two properties was assessable in the hands Of the assessee inasmuch as he had retained a portion of the income from the trust properties for himself. The trust had, therefore, become revocable under the provisions of s. 16  1    c  of the income tax Act 1922, hereinafter called the Act. The Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal affirmed the view taken by the Income tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner affirmed the ITO's view on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal affirmed the view taken by the Income tax Officer. When the matter came before the Appellate Tribunal it found that the assessee had irrevocably parted with the aforesaid two properties and the same had got vested in the trust.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal found that assessee had irrevocably parted with the two properties which vested in the trust.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came before the Appellate Tribunal it found that the assessee had irrevocably parted with the aforesaid two properties and the same had got vested in the trust. It was held that s. 16 1   c  would become applicable only if the setdor preserved to himself the entire income arising from the settled properties if only a portion had been reserved by the settlor it would number make the settlement revocable.

facts.text: Tribunal held s.16(1)(c) applicable only if settlor preserved entire income; portion reserved does not make revocable.

anchor.surface_text: It was held that s. 16 1   c  would become applicable only if the setdor preserved to himself the entire income arising from the settled properties if only a portion had been reserved by the settlor it would number make the settlement revocable. It is number disputed that the total annual income from these properties came to over Rs. 19,000. Out of -this the assessee, who was the settlor, was entitled to Rs. 2,400, - annually.

facts.text: Total annual income from the two properties over Rs. 19,000; not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the total annual income from these properties came to over Rs. 19,000. Out of -this the assessee, who was the settlor, was entitled to Rs. 2,400, - annually. According to the Tribunal only the amount of Rs. 2,400/- which had actually been received by the assessee under the terms of the trust deed companyld be included in his income.

facts.text: Assessee entitled to Rs. 2,400 annually out of the trust income.

facts.text: Tribunal held only Rs. 2,400 actually received by assessee includible in his income.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Tribunal only the amount of Rs. 2,400/- which had actually been received by the assessee under the terms of the trust deed companyld be included in his income. The view of the High Court was that in order to be revocable under the first proviso to s. 16  1   c  it is sufficient if the, settlement, disposition or transfer companytains a provision for retransfer of a part of the income to the settlor,. disposer or transferor.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court held settlement revocable under first proviso to s.16(1)(c) if provision for retransfer of part of income to settlor; entire income includible.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the High Court was that in order to be revocable under the first proviso to s. 16  1   c  it is sufficient if the, settlement, disposition or transfer companytains a provision for retransfer of a part of the income to the settlor,. disposer or transferor. It is number necessary that there must be a provision for the retransfer of the entire income. The word income includes any part of the income unless there is anything repugnant in the companytext.

facts.text: There is no dispute that the trust created was a genuine one.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside the High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is companysequently allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

facts.text: Reference question: Whether entire or any part of income from house properties could be included in assessee's total income u/s 16(1)(c) read with first proviso.

anchor.surface_text: answering the following question of law referred to it against the assessee and in favour of the Revenue Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the entire or any part of the income from the house properties companycerned companyld be included in the total income of the assessee by virtue of the provisions of s. 16   1    c  of the Income tax Act, 1922 read with the first proviso thereto ?

facts.text: Clause (c) introduced in s.16(1) in 1939.

anchor.surface_text: Clause  c  was introduced in s. 16 1  in the year 1939.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Calcutta High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special. leave from a judgment of the Calcutta High Court answering the following question of law referred to it against the assessee and in favour of the Revenue
This is an appeal by special. leave from a judgment of the Calcutta High Court answering the following question of law referred to it against the assessee

Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the entire or any part of the income from the house properties concerned could be included in the total income of the assessee by virtue of the provisions of s. 16   1    c  of the Income tax Act, 1922 read with the first proviso thereto ?

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the entire or any part of the income from the house properties concerned could be included in the total income of the assessee by virtue of the provisions of s. 16(1)(c) of the Income tax Act, 1922 read with the first proviso thereto?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the entire or any part of the income from the house properties concerned could be included in the total income of the assessee by virtue of the provisions of s. 16   1    c  of the Income tax Act, 1922 read with the first proviso thereto ?

issues.text: Whether a provision for retransfer of a part of the income to the settlor renders the settlement revocable under the first proviso to s. 16(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act, 1922?

issues.text: Whether the third proviso to s. 16(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act, 1922 excludes from the settlor's income the portion of income given to other beneficiaries in a settlement deemed revocable under the first proviso?

It is number necessary that there must be a provision for the retransfer of the entire income. The word income includes any part of the income unless there is anything repugnant in the companytext.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed that part suffices for revocability under first proviso.

arguments.claim: Third proviso to s.16(1)(c) does not explain first proviso but is a rider or exception; settlement with part retransfer provision is revocable in entirety, attracting substantive clause for full income taxation.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court considered, that the third proviso to S. 1 6  1   c  did number explain the first proviso but was a kind of rider or exception to it. Bearing in mind the object behind the enactment of s. 16 and on a consideration of the terms of the section the true meaning and scope of the, first proviso seemed to be that the settlement in the present case was revocable in its entirety thus attracting the substantive clause of s. 16  1   c .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: urther from which income the settlor derives numberdirect or indirect benefit. Chagla J., as he then was. delivered a separate judgment although he ag

arguments.court_reasoning: Third proviso limits application even to first-proviso deemed revocable settlements, excluding non-settlor beneficiaries' income if conditions met.

arguments.claim: Scheme of s.16(1)(c): First determine revocability per first proviso (includes part); if yes, then apply third proviso which excludes income to others if not revocable >6 years/lifetime and no settlor benefit beyond.

anchor.surface_text: In Ramji Keshavji v. Commissioner of ,Income tax Bombay 1 , the Bombay High Court considered the scheme of s. 16 1  c . According to that decision the first stage is that when there is a revocable transfer of assets. The income derived from such assets is still to be considered the income of the settlor. The first proviso specifies what would be deemed a revocable transfer in spite of the deed being apparently irrevocable.

arguments.claim: Third proviso contains limitation applying to substantive clause (c) and first proviso; excludes settlor's tax on others' shares if conditions fulfilled, even if settlor beneficiary for part.

anchor.surface_text: Chagla J., as he then was. delivered a separate judgment although he agreed with the answer given to the reference by Kania J. In his opinion the only way to reconcile the substantive provision of sub-cl.  c , Provisos  1  and  3  was to hold that proviso  3  contained a limitation which applied as much to the substantive provisions of sub-clause  c  as to proviso  1

arguments.claim: Third proviso does not exclude settlor's own beneficiary income but excludes shares to other beneficiaries if conditions met; applies to first-proviso deemed revocable settlements.

anchor.surface_text: The third proviso to s. 16  1   c  does number operate to exclude the income which the settlor receives as a beneficiary, from liability to income tax it merely excludes that part of the income which is under the deed of settlement given to another person from liability to tax in the hands of the settlor, if the conditions prescribed by the third proviso are fulfilled.

arguments.claim: Settlement containing provision for retransfer of part income does not render whole income chargeable if third proviso conditions satisfied; only others' shares excluded from settlor's tax.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the above principles it would number be wrong to say that the effect of the third proviso is that a settlement or disposition containing a provision for retransfer of a part of the income to the settlor would number render the whole income of the  1  13 I.T.R. 105  2   1964  7 SCR 920 settlement chargeable in his hand provided the other conditions contained in the proviso are satisfied.

arguments.claim: 1961 Act s.63 explicitly deems revocable for 'whole or any part', indicating 1922 Act did not clearly cover 'part' for full taxation.

anchor.surface_text: We may also refer to the significant change made in the language with regard to revocable transfers in the Income tax Act 1961. Section, 63 of that Act provides For the purposes of section 60, 61 and 62 and of this Section-  a  a transfer shall be deemed to be revocable if- it contains any provision for the retransfer directly or indirectly of the whole or any part of the income or assets to the transferor

arguments.claim: Trust genuine and fulfills third proviso conditions; only settlor's received income assessable, not others' shares.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute in the present case that the trust created was a genuine one. Since it fulfilled the conditions laid down in the third proviso only that part. of the income which accrued or was received by the settlor could be assessed as his income. The income accruing to the. other beneficiaries could number be included in the total income. of the assessee.

holdings.text: A settlement or disposition is deemed revocable under the first proviso to s. 16(1)(c) of the Income-tax Act, 1922 if it contains a provision for the retransfer of a part of the income to the settlor.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the High Court was that in order to be revocable under the first proviso to s. 16  1   c  it is sufficient if the, settlement, disposition or transfer contains a provision for retransfer of a part of the income to the settlor,. disposer or transferor. It is not necessary that there must be a provision for the retransfer of the entire income. The word income includes any part of the income unless there is anything repugnant in the context.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Income' in first proviso includes any part thereof unless repugnant to context; follows textual interpretation and High Court view.

holdings.text: The third proviso to s. 16(1)(c) applies to settlements deemed revocable under the first proviso and excludes from the settlor's income the income arising to other beneficiaries if the conditions of the third proviso are fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: Chagla J., as he then was. delivered a separate judgment although he agreed with the answer given to the reference by Kania J. In his opinion the only way to reconcile the substantive provision of sub-cl.  c , Provisos  1  and  3  was to hold that proviso  3  contained a limitation which applied as much to the substantive provisions of sub-clause  c  as to proviso  1  13 I.T.R. 105. The view expressed in the Ramji Keshavji case 1  was approved by this Court in C.I.T. Patna v. Rani Bhuvaneshwari Kuer 2

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of clause (c), first and third provisos; follows precedents (Ramji Keshavji, Rani Bhuvaneshwari Kuer) holding third proviso limits both substantive clause and first proviso.

holdings.text: The effect of the third proviso is that a settlement containing a provision for retransfer of a part of the income to the settlor does not render the whole income chargeable in his hands provided other conditions in the third proviso are satisfied; income settled on third persons is assessed in their hands, not settlor's.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the above principles it would not be wrong to say that the effect of the third proviso is that a settlement or disposition containing a provision for retransfer of a part of the income to the settlor would not render the whole income of the  1  13 I.T.R. 105  2   1964  7 SCR 920 settlement chargeable in his hand provided the other conditions contained in the proviso are satisfied. In other words the proviso comes to the rescue of the settlor in that the portion of the income from the trust properties which are settled on a third person is to be assessed in the hands of that person and not in the hand of the settlor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Third proviso rescues settlor from taxation on third parties' shares if no power to deflect for required period; settlement not wholly within mischief if revocability only partial; follows Rani Bhuvaneshwari and Jitendranath Mallick.

holdings.text: In the facts of this case, only that part of the income which accrued to or was received by the settlor (Rs. 2,400) could be assessed as his income; the income accruing to other beneficiaries could not be included in the assessee-settlor's total income.

anchor.surface_text: There is no dispute in the present case that the trust created was a genuine one. Since it fulfilled the conditions laid down in the third proviso only that part. of the income which accrued or was received by the settlor could be assessed as his income. The income accruing to the. other beneficiaries could not be included in the total income. of the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Genuine irrevocable trust for required period; settlor derives benefit only from his share; third proviso conditions satisfied excluding others' income.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed and the judgment of the Calcutta High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is consequently allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in holding entire income includible; correct position is only settlor's share taxable per s.16(1)(c) third proviso.

According to that decision the first stage is that when there is a revocable transfer of assets. The income derived from such assets is still to be companysidered the income of the settlor.

precedents.cited_proposition: scheme of s. 16(1)(c) including how the substantive clause and provisos operate, particularly that proviso 3 limits application even if transfer deemed revocable under proviso 1
precedents.cited_holding: although in fact, after reading the provision of s. 16 1   c  with proviso  1 , the transfer is revocable, the law will number still companysider the income derived from such settlement, the income of the setlor, provided the settlement is number revocable for a period exceeding, six years or during the lifetime of the person for whom the incomes is settled, and, further from which income the settlor derives numberdirect or indirect benefit

anchor.surface_text: C.I.T. Patna v. Rani Bhuvaneshwari Kuer 2 . In that case the assessee, who owned an estate known as Tekari Raj, created a trust with a view to liquidate the debts of Tekari Raj. The beneficiaries under the deed were the settlor, her husband and her sons.

precedents.case_name: CIT Patna v Rani Bhuvaneshwari Kuer
precedents.cited_proposition: third proviso to s.16(1)(c) excludes income given to others from settlor's assessment if conditions met, even if settlor receives part as beneficiary; provisos 1 and 2 are explanatory and third proviso applies to deemed revocable settlements
precedents.cited_holding: The third proviso to s. 16  1   c  does number operate to exclude the income which the settlor receives as a beneficiary, from liability to income tax it merely excludes that part of the income which is under the deed of settlement given to another person from liability to tax in the hands of the settlor, if the companyditions prescribed by the third proviso are fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: See C.I.T. Calcutta Jitendranath Mallick 1  We are in entire agreement with the above view of the Cal- cutta High Court and companysider that the same is supported by the decision of this companyrt in Rani Bhuvaneshwari Kuers case 1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: settlement containing provision for retransfer of only part of income does not make whole settlement revocable under s.16(1)(c)

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is companysequently allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed and judgment of the High Court set aside; only the Rs. 2,400/- income received by the assessee/settlor under the trust deed is includible in his total income, not the income to other beneficiaries.

anchor.surface_text: The view of the High Court was that in order to be revocable under the first proviso to s. 16  1   c  it is sufficient if the, settlement, disposition or transfer contains a provision for retransfer of a part of the income to the settlor,. disposer or transferor. It is not necessary that there must be a provision for the retransfer of the entire income. The word income includes any part of the income unless there is anything repugnant in the context.
The appeal is companysequently allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Chagla J., as he then was. delivered a separate judgment although he agreed with the answer given to the reference by Kania J. In his opinion the only way to reconcile the substantive provision of sub-cl.  c , Provisos  1  and  3  was to hold that proviso  3  contained a limitation which applied as much to the substantive provisions of sub-clause  c  as to proviso  1  13 I.T.R. 105. The view expressed in the Ramji Keshavji case 1  was approved by this Court in C.I.T. Patna v. Rani Bhuvaneshwari Kuer 2
The appeal is companysequently allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the light of the above principles it would not be wrong to say that the effect of the third proviso is that a settlement or disposition containing a provision for retransfer of a part of the income to the settlor would not render the whole income of the  1  13 I.T.R. 105  2   1964  7 SCR 920 settlement chargeable in his hand provided the other conditions contained in the proviso are satisfied. In other words the proviso comes to the rescue of the settlor in that the portion of the income from the trust properties which are settled on a third person is to be assessed in the hands of that person and not in the hand of the settlor
The appeal is companysequently allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: There is no dispute in the present case that the trust created was a genuine one. Since it fulfilled the conditions laid down in the third proviso only that part. of the income which accrued or was received by the settlor could be assessed as his income. The income accruing to the. other beneficiaries could not be included in the total income. of the assessee.
The appeal is companysequently allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.
The appeal is companysequently allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside.
